definitions.definition: to raise somebody/something or be raised to a higher position or level
definitions.sensetop: lift somebody/somethinglift somebody/something uplift somebody/something (up) + adv./prep.

examples.text: I lifted the lid of the box and peered in.
She **lifted her head** to look at him.
He lifted the toddler up and cuddled her.
He stood there with his arms lifted above his head.
John lifted his eyes *(= looked up)* from his book.
Her eyebrows lifted. ‘Apologize? Why?’
His head lifted sharply
Juliet nodded, lifting her face to David's.
The box was so heavy I could barely lift it.

definitions.definition: to take hold of somebody/something and move them/it to a different position

examples.text: I lifted the baby out of the chair.
He lifted the suitcase down from the rack.
Carefully lift the cake off the tray and cool on a wire rack.
She lifted the book up off the table.
He felt as if an enormous weight had been lifted from his shoulders.
She lifted the child over the fence.
He hugged her, almost lifting her off the ground.
She was lifted bodily aboard by two sailors.
He leaned on her and she half lifted him down the stairs.
She lifted back the sheet.
The heavy beams were lifted into place.

definitions.definition: to transport people or things by air

examples.text: The survivors were lifted to safety by helicopter.

definitions.definition: to give somebody/something the ability to escape from a difficult situation

examples.text: The best way to lift nations out of poverty is through trade.

definitions.definition: to remove or end controls or limits

examples.text: The government decided to **lift the ban** on arms exports.
to **lift sanctions/restrictions**
The US remained opposed to lifting the embargo.
Martial law has now been lifted.
The police managed to restore calm and the curfew was partially lifted.

definitions.definition: to become or make somebody more cheerful

examples.text: His heart lifted at the sight of her.
The news lifted our spirits.
The fog began to lift.
Gradually my depression started to lift.
The fog suddenly lifted.
He had been lifting electrical goods from the store where he worked.

definitions.definition: to use somebody’s ideas or words without asking permission or without saying where they come from

examples.text: She lifted most of the ideas from a book she had been reading.
lines lifted from a famous poem

definitions.definition: to dig up vegetables or plants from the ground

examples.text: to lift potatoes

definitions.definition: to make the amount or level of something greater; to become greater in amount or level

examples.text: Interest rates were lifted yesterday.
The redevelopment along the river should help lift property prices in the area.

definitions.definition: to do nothing to help somebody

examples.text: The children never lift a finger to help around the house.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old Norse lypta, of Germanic origin; related to loft.
